It belongs to the legume family, Fabaceae, and is characterized by its phyllodes, which are flattened, leaf-like structures that reduce water loss. The plant produces yellow flowers in globular clusters, typically blooming in spring. It is adapted to arid and semi-arid environments, making it a hardy species suitable for dry climates. Acacia gilbertii is also valued for its role in soil stabilization and as a source of nectar for native pollinators.

Acacia gilbertii plays an important ecological role in supporting local wildlife and stabilizing soil in its native range.
